Its a good game but not a good successor to previous game. CoH 2 had WW2 visual in evey bit of the game, from menu to the after game reports. CoH3 is has no soul on that regard and in game visuals feel all rainbow and sunshine, not blood and guts.

Relic really turned around the Company of Heroes 3 ship a lot faster than they did with the CoH2 launch, but the game was also in a better state on launch than CoH2 imo.

Overall its probably my favorite Company of Heroes game now for PvP and the most fun I've had in a CoH game. Not only is it the active one so the meta shakes up once and awhile, but starting with 4 fleshed out factions really makes the game feel complete without needing any DLC. Before DLC this is the most amount of content a base CoH game has ever had both SP and MP wise. (Though it really needs that on the SP side, as it doesnt have any SP expansions yet like previous games.) 

The Battlegroups are are also sooo much better than Commanders from CoH2, with no 1:1 re-used abilities and flexible trees for different playstyles or adjusting to game states in the same battlegroup. They really pack in a lot of gameplay with the 3 each faction gets, way more than CoH1 or CoH2 had on offer even after DLC imo due to no re-use of units and abilities. Tbh Relic has also been cookin' with the DLC Battlegroups too, typical new large patch RTS meta discovery and the balance of unforeseen discoveries aside.

The direction Relic has been taking the design is fairly good, though I slightly worry that they may get too close to CoH2s infantry lethality with all the DPS increases that they keep creeping into each patch. The game feel is like a mix between CoH1 and fresh CoH3 feel more than it feels like CoH2. Early infantry fights are pretty deadly and positional, but as durability gets acquired by Veterancy they still have good use in the later stages of the game compared to previous titles. The way the factions work and build is a mix of new ideas and some nostalgia with how the game pace and factions worked in CoH1, no weird CoH1 British or CoH2 USF thankfully though.

The SP content has been my favorite since CoH1, and while theres more on launch than before, though the DLCs for 1 and 2 really added a lot of SP content, so in a way CoH3 does have to catch up still. The linear campaign is about as good as CoH1s and better than 2s, but not my favorite linear campaign from the franchise. The Italian Total-War-esque campaign is a lot of fun though, only Operation Stonewall in CoH1 felt as fun but that might mostly be nostalgia. (Would really like a in-depth Stonewall-like mode for CoH3 with its own units/abilities). The AI feels a bit more fair and does more-player like moves, it is at the cost of being easier to fight though, which can get boring if you are a above average player.

I haven't even gone into all the excellent quality of life the game adds like auto-reinforce, the lowest mouse delay and smoothest pathfinding the games have seen with all the fixes they've done, fully rebind-able keys including double binds and the ability to set up a WASD camera. There's also new features like side-hits on tanks, high ground, many never before done unit types and abilities, and my favorite, towing, with the really cool heavy towed AT guns that centerstage the mechanic. 

Is good RTS game.
The game has come a long way. Visually, it blows the earlier versions away. Gameplay is fun and varied.

After a rocky launch, i really have to give credit where credit is due. Relic not giving up on the game post partum, and actually coming out with updates, bug fixes, maps, and DLC that gives players fun options and variations to play the game, is really nice to see in a day and age where RTS games come often or not, dead on arrival. 
Having been an avid RTS player on and off for over 20 years, all the way from the C&C, SC and SC2, Supreme  Commander to now COH, i'm more than pleased to say that this scratches the RTS itch that i've been missing lately. Although the game doesn't have the extensive base building mechanics and resource managing, akin to these other RTS games, it changes it out for intuitive gameplay features and styles, where the battle is won in how you play your units, instead of having to play 5D sim city inside your base with an APM of over 900. 
This game's "easy to pickup and hard to master" playstyle has worked well in getting me and my friends who aren't as experienced in RTS, to enjoy this "historically authentic" all out war strategy game. This game has awesome battlefield-esque moments, with explosions, gunfire and limbs being flung all over the place, and it took quite a hold on us. For those saying the game looks "cartoony", i have yet to spot that. Although some of the voice lines are a tad on the cheesy side.
Some of the DLC Battlegroups had early issues, with OP general purpose units (ranger blobs), and sim city bunker playstyles from some of the Wehrmacht BG's, and also just useless units in general (the toothless King tiger, oh how the mighty have fallen), we have after several updates achieved a more "balanced" state of play, both in teamplay and solos.


There is an elephant in the room though, and i'm not talking about the Ferdinand. 
The cost of some of these battlegroups, and also for some of these skins (if i can even call them that), is ridiculous and bordering to egregious. Having fun new units locked behind a paywall can be considered ok, since it's adding to the game in fun and different ways to play, but locking META units and BG's behind a paywall is unacceptable. The period of time where i had to fight against ranger blobs, or entire battalions of invisible mg42 teams, while i was fighting with vanilla units that seem to be made out of paper towels in comparison, was a constant uphill battle. After some time, they finally changed it up and made some of the older BG's more viable, but i'm still holding a bit of skepticism towards the new BG's coming to Scarlet Bison, seeing how insane some of these new abilites can be (laser guided missile for DAK btw :P).

If you have seen the "store" in this game you will be met with lack luster skins that are in different shades of mud and shit, for a hefty price of 20$ on some of these. I appreciate the historically "accuracy" in some of these skins, but 20$ for smearing some leaves and kaka on my tank? Really? Might be rose tinted glasses but some of the skins from COH2 were more creative, and the ability to use custom ones from Steam Workshop was amazing, but alas money talks.

I've been craving a competetive RTS that I could try to master, something that was strategically rich, with a healthy matchmaking pool. StarCraft2 was always too "twitchy" for me, and I could never play more than a game before feeling strung out. BAR might be the most comprehensive RTS I've ever seen, but it's heavyweight and feels like you need a PHD to reach basic competency. CoH3 is refined, with enough variety to offer real expression in how you play, and paced just right so each battle is a sequence of meaningful decisions, reactions, and gambits.

CoH3 is relic at their finest. The territory based resource system encourages fun game play. Push and pull across the map, manoeuvring and out manoeuvring, flanking and traps. The limitations on units you can field means you are encouraged to be deliberate about your investment choices, and it's about how you use your units, not how many you have. The crescendo of the battle is excellent. Veterancy means your initial units remain important to your strategy even as the battle escalates. The escalation through light, medium and heavy armour presents very real shifts in the battle dynamic.

There is a ton of emergent strategy. Line of sight, accuracy, elevation, movement, damage and range, armour and health - it all *makes sense*, and diving deeper into the mechanics and stats of your units can be really rewarding, offering you a tactical edge.

The allies vs axis dichotomy allows the game to have the variety of 4 factions, but with a much lower match up burden. Choose your favourite, and know that the opponent can only be one of two core options. Battlegroups are a great way to add variety without a huge knowledge burden. I was very happy playing DAK Italian infantry, and branched out to try combined arms when I wanted to. I'm 200+ hours in now and am quite comfortable with most of the DAK battle groups, and am excited to try out an ally faction in a similar way.

I don't really engage much with the cosmetics being sold, and I don't feel I need to. I'll pay for something if I think it looks worthwhile, like new battlegroups if I think they will be fun to use and give me cool new strategies to try.

I have been playing all Company of Heroes Games in the past weeks. Here are some thoughts on how these games compare to one another. This review is soley focused on the singleplayer aspects of the game. I did play skrimishes against the AI, but they tend to get boring very fast, if you dont have the choices of commanders you do from CoH2.

Loving the campaign style of CoH3. The colors are bright which can put you off, if you're used to battles on the eastern front of CoH2 or the grimey visuals of CoH1. I dont mind as much. The colors feel like Italy if that makes sense. Its quite the contrast to the harsh reality of war. 

Gameplay is not as finicky as in CoH1. There is a button to reverse vehicles. Very nice. Veterancy system now has two options to choose from, meaning more flexibility on how to deal with the enemy. E.g. If you play with the US, your rifle squad can either go fast, or do suppressing fire. Running faster is nice, if you encounter an enemy who uses mortars and keeps you moving your troops. If your enemy has more of a static frontline and loves to charge with blobs of infantry, the covering fire gives you a good boost to rate of fire and you deal more suppression damage. In addtion there is a new breach mechanic for infantry, meaning you can storm occupied buildings. I dont use it very often, but it's nice to have that choice.

Campaign for CoH3 gets a bit repetetive. I would've loved more handcrafted missions. Or at least more dynamic skirmishes. Relic did patch in a few more, but they do tend to be samey. Units on the strategic map are sometimes a bit weird to move around. You can customize each unit on the strat map to be to your liking. However upgrading your units on the strategic map is only really a question of choice in the earlier parts. Taking inspiration from CoH2 US campaign would've been nice. If every unit is unique, it's always a question of how to play it.

My favorite unit is the special forces. The SSF Commandos are really powerful, because they do it all. The can hide in cover, the can switch from rifles to bazookas.

Comparing the SP stuff from 3 to 2, I do love the addition of the strategic part, but I miss the whole story element of the soviet campaign from CoH2 (that was really a blast). The comparison to movies and tv shows is not far of. In that sense I would've loved a campaign for the SAS (the tv show called "SAS: Rogue Heroes" is fun and a good watch); either with a strategic map in north africa leading up to the Italy campaign, or a campaign in the style of the soviet one in CoH2.

But there is no beating the the good campaigns of CoH1. These were some of the best RTS campaigns I've ever played. CoH2 felt too short in that regard, and CoH3 lacks the story depth of both 1 and 2. There are some story elements hidding in CoH3, but it's just not enough.

Would I recommend Company of Heroes 3 right now? It depends. If your a junkie for Online Matchmaking stay with CoH2 for now. If you like the war stories from 1, also stay away for now.

If you want a new strategic experience in the clothes of a game, you are familiar with, then this is the game for you. It changes things up a bit, but not too much.

[h1]Company of Heroes 3 - Review[/h1]

[b]Playtime disclosure:[/b] ~130 hours
[b]Platform:[/b] PC via Steam

[h2]Summary[/h2]
Company of Heroes 3 is a modern, high-quality WWII RTS that delivers strong campaigns, polished presentation, and reliable performance. The official map roster could be broader for certain modes, but Steam Workshop support and an active community add real depth. With a larger nation lineup, it could become "the" WWII RTS to play.

[h2]What CoH3 does well[/h2]
[list]
    [*]Visual and audio quality are excellent. Environments, unit models, and effects look great, and units and characters are properly voiced by human actors, which adds authenticity.
    [*]Terrain deformation and destruction are excellent. Artillery, explosives, and vehicles actively reshape the battlefield, creating craters, breaches, and new sightlines. Deformed terrain provides real defence bonuses to infantry, letting squads use craters and improvised cover to hold ground more effectively.
    [*]Campaigns are engaging and varied, with meaningful strategic choices that keep the experience fresh.
    [*]Stability has been strong across ~130 hours. Bugs or crashes were rare, and almost all were related to mods that needed updates.
    [*]Steam Workshop integration is a standout. Community content is easy to find and install. Recommended mods include Game Modes Plus, AI Plus, and the No Nanny tuning pack.
[/list]

[h2]Where it falls short[/h2]
[list]
    [*]Limited official map selection, especially for 2v2. You can add many high-quality community maps from the Workshop, and Relic has run map-making competitions that produced great results. Even so, more official maps would improve matchmaking variety and balance for 2v2, 4-player, and 6-player games. I have spent at least 80 hours in 2v2, and that bracket needs a deeper pool.
    [*]Faction breadth. I understand that, given the theatre Relic chose for CoH3, they focused on the current four factions. That choice makes sense for the setting. If the roster expanded to include a Russian nation on the Allied side and a Japanese nation on the Axis side, with their own battlegroups, this game would become "the" WWII RTS to play. Relic do not claim it is the best, but with a larger nation lineup it damned well would be.
    [*]DLC pricing. DLC prices are on the higher side. I was comfortable paying them, and I appreciate that Relic bought themselves away from their publisher and returned to self-publishing. That is worth supporting because it gives the developers freedom to make the games they want to make, not just whatever suits a publisher‚Äôs bottom line. With ~130 hours of play and more than A$150 spent across the base game and DLCs, I feel I have absolutely had my money‚Äôs worth.
[/list]

[h2]Wishlist for future updates[/h2]
[list]
    [*]Add a Russian faction (Allies) and a Japanese faction (Axis), each with distinctive battlegroups.
    [*]Expand the official map set for 2v2 in particular, and add more options for 4-player and 6-player matches.
[/list]

[h2]Closing thoughts[/h2]
Ignore the negative comparisons from CoH1 and CoH2 players who expect a carbon copy of earlier titles. CoH3 is an excellent entry in the series on its own terms. I have enjoyed it so much that I have bought and gifted the game and DLCs to friends, just so we can play it together.

Company of Heroes 3 is a real-time strategy game developed by Relic Entertainment that continues the acclaimed World War II series with new mechanics and larger-scale tactical options.

Gameplay combines traditional squad-based combat with a new dynamic campaign map. Players command Allied or Axis forces in Italy and North Africa, managing both battlefield tactics and broader strategic decisions such as capturing towns, securing supply lines, and deploying reinforcements.

Combat remains intense and detail-oriented. Cover, line of sight, and terrain elevation heavily influence engagements. Infantry, armor, and artillery units must be coordinated precisely to exploit enemy weaknesses. Destructible environments return, allowing for tactical adaptation as buildings collapse and terrain changes mid-battle.

The major addition is the dynamic campaign system, functioning like a turn-based layer above real-time battles. It gives players freedom to choose missions, plan offensives, and manage logistics. This hybrid structure expands scope beyond previous entries, introducing a light grand-strategy element.

Visually, Company of Heroes 3 runs on the Essence Engine and delivers realistic lighting, detailed models, and strong environmental destruction effects. The Mediterranean settings are bright and varied, contrasting with the darker tones of earlier games.

Sound design is excellent. Explosions, gunfire, and voice lines are sharp and context-sensitive, while the orchestral score complements both quiet buildup and large-scale assaults. Voice acting and radio chatter enhance immersion and authenticity.

Overall, Company of Heroes 3 evolves the series without losing its tactical identity. It offers more strategic control, improved visuals, and refined combat depth. While the campaign pacing can feel uneven, it remains one of the most complete and engaging modern World War II RTS experiences.

I came here for the campaign experience. It took me 13 hours to complete it at the highest difficulty. 

The have advertized 2.0 patch as to include many campaign improvements. Well, they did improve it, but it buffles me, how it took them 2 years to realize that defensive spots with 20 damage are not worth it.

AI does spawn occasional armies in their cities, but in my entire campaign (at HIGHEST difficulty) they have spawned armies twice. Needless to say, it was a stomp of the campaign map.

AI used like 1 bombing run in entire campaign (on global map), so fighters are useless. Overall, AI does feel dead, as it barely puts any resistance on the global map. I really liked the idea of having this total war kind of map, but ai needs to do stuff...

Campaign economy balance is just bad. It took me 30 turns for the entirety of the campaign (can be done much faster, as I was exploring the game). But how about investing 60 fuel to get +3 munition per turn? 20 turns ROI on a campaign which lasts 30 kekw

Instead the campaign is extremely snowbally. You get like 2-5x more resources through a city capture, then you get per turn. So if you can get to capturing 1-2 cities per turn, your resources will feel infinite. But at the same time, it's a noob trap, as casual players will go for a slower approach, and suffocate from lack of resources.

Lore wise it makes sense that you are capturing local resources, but it could have been 5% of current resources, and a proper economy from cities instead. Also, why do I get resources for defending lol? 

Companies & unit balance is also busted. I get paratroopers with an early skill to have a P-47 straf everything around. No other company skill comes even close. At the same time, having british company assisting is also imba, cause their armoured car is like 5x more effective than the american one (and I mean it with 5x). Churchil is not as good for Antitank but almost as good as a hellcat, while also excels at anti-infantry tasks - and it comes at a cost of 600/100 vs 600/90. 

Call ins should feel op, cause they are special global map abilities. But it should be viable to use different layouts, and not just have a 2-3x better one in any situation.

In-combat AI also appears to be very flawed. Instead of capturing points, they run between them, even if all my units are on the other side of the map. If AI gets cornered into base, they may get stuck in a loop of non stop retreating, the moment they see the army outside, but do not try to go check the other flank.

--------

I do see the effort, and the campaign is better, from what I can judge. But with 2.0 improvements and 2.5 years into release, I doubt we will be seeing any major improvements any time soon, if at all. 

If I am proven wrong, and campaign does get major boost (even if it's a new dlc campaign), I may revisit my review. But so far, it was a meh experience. Also, the entire campaign is about taking Rome, but in the end, you do not even take Rome, instead you capture a random city, and get a cut scene :/

The Italian campaign is pretty fun, but it lacks all the in-game cutscenes and cinematics that help immerse you in the mission and story. I couldn't even finish the North Africa campaign because it's just boring, and the units you're forced to use are so weak it's frustrating.

I don't bother with multiplayer because I can't be bothered with it. I used to love playing skirmishes in CoH1 and CoH2, but there's no real incentive to play them here ‚Äî you don't unlock anything, there's no progression, and the fun wears off quickly.

What happened to the mini-challenge modes and in-depth, story-driven single-player campaigns from CoH2? I thought the whole point of making a new game in a series was to double down on what the previous one did well ‚Äî improving graphics, sound, and overall gameplay.

There's no point in paying real money for those "companies" to get new abilities when you can‚Äôt even use them in single-player campaigns (apart from one British company).
